commit_message:
[WIP] Add scheduler support for VPN service.

As mentioned in specs https://review.openstack.org/#/c/334401/,
for VPN+OVN, VPNaaS needs a new scheduler. This patch adds support
for a VPN scheduler.

This patch depends on following the change:
I4b90288c9c04d0c45ddf4e69f80825a236721781

Depends-On: I4b90288c9c04d0c45ddf4e69f80825a236721781
Change-Id: Icac8686ec9d69e728598b2036023bb1cf06533a2
Partial-Bug: #1586253
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas refs/changes/68/368468/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # (c) Copyright 2016 IBM Corporation, All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import abc import collections import functools import itertools import random from neutron_lib import constants as lib_const from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_db import exception as db_exc from oslo_log import log as logging import six from sqlalchemy import sql from neutron import manager from neutron._i18n import _LE from neutron._i18n import _LW from neutron.common import constants from neutron.common import utils from neutron.db import api as db_api from neutron.db import l3_db from neutron.extensions import availability_zone as az_ext from neutron.extensions import l3 from neutron.plugins.common.constants import L3_ROUTER_NAT from neutron_vpnaas.db.vpn import vpn_agentschedulers_db from neutron_vpnaas.db.vpn import vpn_hamode_db LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) cfg.CONF.register_opts(vpn_hamode_db.VPN_HA_OPTS) @six.add_metaclass(abc.ABCMeta) class VPNScheduler(object): def __init__(self): self.min_ha_agents = cfg.CONF.min_vpn_agents_per_router self.max_ha_agents = cfg.CONF.max_vpn_agents_per_router @property def l3_plugin(self): return manager.NeutronManager.get_service_plugins().get(L3_ROUTER_NAT) @abc.abstractmethod def schedule(self, plugin, context, router_id, candidates=None, hints=None): """Schedule the router to an active VPN agent. Schedule the router only if it is not already scheduled. """ pass def _router_has_binding(self, context, router_id, vpn_agent_id): router_binding_model = vpn_agentschedulers_db.RouterVPNAgentBinding query = context.session.query(router_binding_model) query = query.filter(router_binding_model.router_id == router_id, router_binding_model.vpn_agent_id == vpn_agent_id) return query.count() > 0 def _filter_unscheduled_routers(self, context, plugin, routers): """Filter from list of routers the ones that are not scheduled.""" unscheduled_routers = [] for router in routers: vpn_agents = plugin.get_vpn_agents_hosting_routers( context, [router['id']]) if vpn_agents: LOG.debug('Router %(router_id)s has already been ' 'hosted by VPN agent %(agent_id)s', {'router_id': router['id'], 'agent_id': vpn_agents[0]['id']}) else: unscheduled_routers.append(router) return unscheduled_routers def _get_unscheduled_routers(self, context, plugin): """Get routers with no agent binding.""" # TODO(gongysh) consider the disabled agent's router no_agent_binding = ~sql.exists().where( l3_db.Router.id == vpn_agentschedulers_db.RouterVPNAgentBinding.router_id) query = context.session.query(l3_db.Router.id).filter(no_agent_binding) query = query.filter(l3_db.Router.status == constants.ROUTER_STATUS_ACTIVE) unscheduled_router_ids = [router_id_[0] for router_id_ in query] if unscheduled_router_ids: return self.l3_plugin.get_router( context, filters={'id': unscheduled_router_ids}) return [] def _get_routers_to_schedule(self, context, plugin, router_ids=None): """Verify that the routers specified need to be scheduled. :param context: the context :param plugin: the core plugin :param router_ids: the list of routers to be checked for scheduling :returns: the list of routers to be scheduled """ if router_ids is not None: filters = {'id': router_ids, 'status': [constants.ROUTER_STATUS_ACTIVE]} routers = self.l3_plugin.get_router(context, filters=filters) return self._filter_unscheduled_routers(context, plugin, routers) else: return self._get_unscheduled_routers(context, plugin) def _get_routers_can_schedule(self, context, plugin, routers, vpn_agent): """Get the subset of routers that can be scheduled on the VPN agent.""" ids_to_discard = set() for router in routers: # check if the vpn agent is compatible with the router candidates = plugin.get_vpn_agent_candidates( context, router, [vpn_agent]) if not candidates: ids_to_discard.add(router['id']) return [r for r in routers if r['id'] not in ids_to_discard] def auto_schedule_routers(self, plugin, context, host, router_ids): """Schedule non-hosted routers to VPN Agent running on host. If router_ids is given, each router in router_ids is scheduled if it is not scheduled yet. Otherwise all unscheduled routers are scheduled. Do not schedule the routers which are hosted already by active vpn agents. :returns: True if routers have been successfully assigned to host """ vpn_agent = plugin.get_enabled_agent_on_host( context, lib_const.AGENT_TYPE_L3, host) if not vpn_agent: return False unscheduled_routers = self._get_routers_to_schedule( context, plugin, router_ids) if not unscheduled_routers: if utils.is_extension_supported( plugin, lib_const.L3_HA_MODE_EXT_ALIAS): return self._schedule_ha_routers_to_additional_agent( plugin, context, vpn_agent) target_routers = self._get_routers_can_schedule( context, plugin, unscheduled_routers, vpn_agent) if not target_routers: LOG.warning(_LW('No routers compatible with VPN agent ' 'configuration on host %s'), host) return False self._bind_routers(context, plugin, target_routers, vpn_agent) return True def _get_candidates(self, plugin, context, sync_router): """Return VPN agents where a router could be scheduled.""" with context.session.begin(subtransactions=True): # allow one router is hosted by just # one enabled vpn agent hosting since active is just a # timing problem. Non-active vpn agent can return to # active any time current_vpn_agents = plugin.get_vpn_agents_hosting_routers( context, [sync_router['id']], admin_state_up=True) if current_vpn_agents: LOG.debug('Router %(router_id)s has already been hosted ' 'by VPN agent %(agent_id)s', {'router_id': sync_router['id'], 'agent_id': current_vpn_agents[0]['id']}) return [] active_vpn_agents = plugin.get_vpn_agents(context, active=True) if not active_vpn_agents: LOG.warning(_LW('No active VPN agents')) return [] candidates = plugin.get_vpn_agent_candidates(context, sync_router, active_vpn_agents) if not candidates: LOG.warning(_LW('No VPN agents can host the router %s'), sync_router['id']) return candidates def _bind_routers(self, context, plugin, routers, vpn_agent): for router in routers: if router.get('ha'): if not self._router_has_binding(context, router['id'], vpn_agent.id): self.create_ha_port_and_bind( plugin, context, router['id'], router['tenant_id'], vpn_agent) else: self.bind_router(context, router['id'], vpn_agent) def bind_router(self, context, router_id, chosen_agent): """Bind the router to the vpn agent which has been chosen.""" try: with context.session.begin(subtransactions=True): binding = vpn_agentschedulers_db.RouterVPNAgentBinding() binding.vpn_agent = chosen_agent binding.router_id = router_id context.session.add(binding) except db_exc.DBDuplicateEntry: LOG.debug('Router %(router_id)s has already been scheduled ' 'to VPN agent %(agent_id)s.', {'agent_id': chosen_agent.id, 'router_id': router_id}) return except db_exc.DBReferenceError: LOG.debug('Router %s has already been removed ' 'by concurrent operation', router_id) return LOG.debug('Router %(router_id)s is scheduled to VPN agent ' '%(agent_id)s', {'router_id': router_id, 'agent_id': chosen_agent.id}) def _schedule_router(self, plugin, context, router_id, candidates=None): sync_router = self.l3_plugin.get_router(context, router_id) candidates = candidates or self._get_candidates( plugin, context, sync_router) if not candidates: return elif sync_router.get('ha', False): chosen_agents = self._bind_ha_router(plugin, context, router_id, candidates) if not chosen_agents: return chosen_agent = chosen_agents[-1] else: chosen_agent = self._choose_router_agent( plugin, context, candidates) self.bind_router(context, router_id, chosen_agent) return chosen_agent @abc.abstractmethod def _choose_router_agent(self, plugin, context, candidates): """Choose an agent from candidates based on a specific policy.""" pass @abc.abstractmethod def _choose_router_agents_for_ha(self, plugin, context, candidates): """Choose agents from candidates based on a specific policy.""" pass def _get_num_of_agents_for_ha(self, candidates_count): return (min(self.max_ha_agents, candidates_count) if self.max_ha_agents else candidates_count) def _enough_candidates_for_ha(self, candidates): if not candidates or len(candidates) < self.min_ha_agents: LOG.error(_LE("Not enough candidates, a HA router needs at least " "%s agents"), self.min_ha_agents) return False return True def _add_port_from_net(self, plugin, ctxt, router_id, tenant_id, ha_net): """small wrapper function to unpack network id from ha_network""" return plugin.add_ha_port(ctxt, router_id, ha_net.network.id, tenant_id) def create_ha_port_and_bind(self, plugin, context, router_id, tenant_id, agent): """Creates and binds a new HA port for this agent.""" ctxt = context.elevated() creator = functools.partial(self._add_port_from_net, plugin, ctxt, router_id, tenant_id) dep_getter = functools.partial(plugin.get_ha_network, ctxt, tenant_id) dep_creator = functools.partial(plugin._create_ha_network, ctxt, tenant_id) dep_deleter = functools.partial(plugin._delete_ha_network, ctxt) dep_id_attr = 'network_id' try: port_binding = utils.create_object_with_dependency( creator, dep_getter, dep_creator, dep_id_attr, dep_deleter)[0] with db_api.autonested_transaction(context.session): port_binding.vpn_agent_id = agent['id'] except db_exc.DBDuplicateEntry: LOG.debug("Router %(router)s already scheduled for agent " "%(agent)s", {'router': router_id, 'agent': agent['id']}) except l3.RouterNotFound: LOG.debug('Router %s has already been removed ' 'by concurrent operation', router_id) return self.bind_router(context, router_id, agent) def get_ha_routers_vpn_agents_counts(self, context, plugin, filters=None): """Return a mapping (router, # agents) matching specified filters.""" return plugin.get_ha_routers_vpn_agents_count(context) def _schedule_ha_routers_to_additional_agent(self, plugin, context, agent): """Bind already scheduled routers to the agent. Retrieve the number of agents per router and check if the router has to be scheduled on the given agent if max_vpn_agents_per_router is not yet reached. """ routers_agents = self.get_ha_routers_vpn_agents_counts(context, plugin, agent) scheduled = False admin_ctx = context.elevated() underscheduled_routers = [router for router, agents in routers_agents if (not self.max_ha_agents or agents < self.max_ha_agents)] schedulable_routers = self._get_routers_can_schedule( admin_ctx, plugin, underscheduled_routers, agent) for router in schedulable_routers: if not self._router_has_binding(admin_ctx, router['id'], agent.id): self.create_ha_port_and_bind(plugin, admin_ctx, router['id'], router['tenant_id'], agent) scheduled = True return scheduled def _bind_ha_router_to_agents(self, plugin, context, router_id, chosen_agents): port_bindings = plugin.get_ha_router_port_bindings(context, [router_id]) for port_binding, agent in zip(port_bindings, chosen_agents): try: with db_api.autonested_transaction(context.session): port_binding.vpn_agent_id = agent.id self.bind_router(context, router_id, agent) except db_exc.DBDuplicateEntry: LOG.debug("Router %(router)s already scheduled for agent " "%(agent)s", {'router': router_id, 'agent': agent.id}) else: LOG.debug('HA Router %(router_id)s is scheduled to VPN agent ' '%(agent_id)s)', {'router_id': router_id, 'agent_id': agent.id}) def _bind_ha_router(self, plugin, context, router_id, candidates): """Bind a HA router to agents based on a specific policy.""" if not self._enough_candidates_for_ha(candidates): return chosen_agents = self._choose_router_agents_for_ha( plugin, context, candidates) self._bind_ha_router_to_agents(plugin, context, router_id, chosen_agents) return chosen_agents class ChanceScheduler(VPNScheduler): """Randomly allocate an VPN agent for a router.""" def schedule(self, plugin, context, router_id, candidates=None): return self._schedule_router( plugin, context, router_id, candidates=candidates) def _choose_router_agent(self, plugin, context, candidates): return random.choice(candidates) def _choose_router_agents_for_ha(self, plugin, context, candidates): num_agents = self._get_num_of_agents_for_ha(len(candidates)) return random.sample(candidates, num_agents) class LeastRoutersScheduler(VPNScheduler): """Allocate to an VPN agent with the least number of routers bound.""" def schedule(self, plugin, context, router_id, candidates=None): return self._schedule_router( plugin, context, router_id, candidates=candidates) def _choose_router_agent(self, plugin, context, candidates): candidate_ids = [candidate['id'] for candidate in candidates] chosen_agent = plugin.get_vpn_agent_with_min_routers( context, candidate_ids) return chosen_agent def _choose_router_agents_for_ha(self, plugin, context, candidates): num_agents = self._get_num_of_agents_for_ha(len(candidates)) ordered_agents = plugin.get_vpn_agents_ordered_by_num_routers( context, [candidate['id'] for candidate in candidates]) return ordered_agents[:num_agents] class AZLeastRoutersScheduler(LeastRoutersScheduler): """Availability zone aware scheduler. If a router is ha router, allocate VPN agents distributed AZs according to router's az_hints. """ def _get_az_hints(self, router): return (router.get(az_ext.AZ_HINTS) or cfg.CONF.default_availability_zones) def _get_routers_can_schedule(self, context, plugin, routers, vpn_agent): """Overwrite VPNScheduler's method to filter by availability zone.""" target_routers = [] for r in routers: az_hints = self._get_az_hints(r) if not az_hints or vpn_agent['availability_zone'] in az_hints: target_routers.append(r) if not target_routers: return return super(AZLeastRoutersScheduler, self)._get_routers_can_schedule( context, plugin, target_routers, vpn_agent) def _get_candidates(self, plugin, context, sync_router): """Overwrite VPNScheduler's method to filter by availability zone.""" all_candidates = ( super(AZLeastRoutersScheduler, self)._get_candidates( plugin, context, sync_router)) candidates = [] az_hints = self._get_az_hints(sync_router) for agent in all_candidates: if not az_hints or agent['availability_zone'] in az_hints: candidates.append(agent) return candidates def get_ha_routers_vpn_agents_counts(self, context, plugin, filters=None): """Overwrite VPNScheduler's method to filter by availability zone.""" all_routers_agents = ( super(AZLeastRoutersScheduler, self). get_ha_routers_vpn_agents_counts(context, plugin, filters)) if filters is None: return all_routers_agents routers_agents = [] for router, agents in all_routers_agents: az_hints = self._get_az_hints(router) if az_hints and filters['availability_zone'] not in az_hints: continue routers_agents.append((router, agents)) return routers_agents def _choose_router_agents_for_ha(self, plugin, context, candidates): ordered_agents = plugin.get_vpn_agents_ordered_by_num_routers( context, [candidate['id'] for candidate in candidates]) num_agents = self._get_num_of_agents_for_ha(len(ordered_agents)) # Order is kept in each az group_by_az = collections.defaultdict(list) for agent in ordered_agents: az = agent['availability_zone'] group_by_az[az].append(agent) selected_agents = [] for az, agents in itertools.cycle(group_by_az.items()): if not agents: continue selected_agents.append(agents.pop(0)) if len(selected_agents) >= num_agents: break return selected_agents

commit_message:
Add support for ingress bandwidth limit rules in ovs agent

Add openvswitch agent support for ingress bandwidth limiting.
It use default ovs QoS policies on bandwidth limiting mechanism.

DocImpact: Ingress bandwidth limit in QoS supported by Openvswitch agent

Co-Authored-By: Gal Sagie <gal.sagie@huawei.com>

Change-Id: If85516f07646e2858f38305c303cb3f7c7026e9c
Depends-on: Iab86c77366bb3290c17f58f6a5a2a206414e49b
Partial-Bug: #1560961

added_lines: def test_ingress_bw_limit(self): port_name, _ = self.create_ovs_port() self.br.update_ingress_bw_limit_for_port(port_name, 700, 70) max_rate, burst = self.br.get_ingress_bw_limit_for_port(port_name) self.assertEqual(700, max_rate) self.assertEqual(70, burst) self.br.update_ingress_bw_limit_for_port(port_name, 750, 100) max_rate, burst = self.br.get_ingress_bw_limit_for_port(port_name) self.assertEqual(750, max_rate) self.assertEqual(100, burst) self.br.delete_ingress_bw_limit_for_port(port_name) max_rate, burst = self.br.get_ingress_bw_limit_for_port(port_name) self.assertIsNone(max_rate) self.assertIsNone(burst) self.assertEqual(tags_present, len_0_list)

Add UT for error from NeutronClientException with lazy translation

Follow-up patch of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/288301/

Change-Id: Ibf17c0306e49e618e4866c2f7efff79461f236d1
Related-Bug: #1552760
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient refs/changes/64/288864/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2016 NEC Corporation # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import oslo_i18n import testtools from neutronclient.common import exceptions class TestExceptions(testtools.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestExceptions, self).setUp() oslo_i18n.enable_lazy() self.addCleanup(oslo_i18n.enable_lazy, False) def _test_neutron_client_exceptions(self, *args, **kwargs): def raise_exception(*_args, **_kwargs): raise exceptions.NeutronClientException(*_args, **_kwargs) self.assertRaises(exceptions.NeutronClientException, raise_exception, *args, **kwargs) def test_neutron_client_exception_ascii_message(self): self._test_neutron_client_exceptions('ascii message') def test_neutron_client_exception_multibyte_message(self): self._test_neutron_client_exceptions(u'\u3042\u3044\u3046') def test_neutron_client_exception_ascii_message_with_reqid(self): self._test_neutron_client_exceptions('ascii message', req_ids=['req-id1']) def test_neutron_client_exception_multibyte_message_with_reqid(self): self._test_neutron_client_exceptions(u'\u3042\u3044\u3046', req_ids=['req-id1'])

commit_message:
[rally-jobs] use jinja variables

Before loading tasks as yaml/json, Rally processes them as jinja templates.
It means that we can move some hardcoded values to jinja variables.

Change-Id: I27402b54685d9366f1fb26a6ff0c337936a350f6

commit_message:
[rally-jobs] Increase number of tenants

The real cloud doesn't have only one tenant with one user in it, so let's
increase rally task to create at least 5 tenants(each iteration is launched
by random tenant by default)

Change-Id: Id28e87be3cb871a7ead5df915fea6a8563a9716d

commit_message:
Change user for calico-dhcp-agent

By default the calico dhcp agent want's to run as root.
A lot of trouble is avoided if the agent runs as the neutron user,
like the neutron dhcp agent. These changes accomplishes that by
changing the user in the systemd unit file and ensures that the
logging directory is present with correct permissions.

This creates a dependency to openstack-neutron-common, since
that package creates the neutron user and installs the
necessary rootwrap scripts.

Change-Id: Ie7124ab11d3ad3b94b8019caf45e7e95a7517545

commit_message:
Propagate revision_number bump to AMQP consumers

revision_number is bumped for networks on subnet update but this
change is not disseminated to the proper network resources. This
change explicitly calls update_network within update_subnet.

Change-Id: I31e646bc118e9e5b8397aa7ec3a19589648ee534
Closes-Bug: #1619253

commit_message:
Add fixed IPs to ns-dhcp

This adds fixed IPs corresponding to subnets without gateways to
ns-dhcp port on its creation. So that dnsmasq could get requests and
answer via that IP to instances when they look for DHCP server.

Change-Id: I4adbc1fa17b49d60b559966f7ccd29282352da3c
Closes-Bug: 1541490

commit_message:
Fixes the SNI issues in master(mitaka) for octavia

1. Fixes the mismatch between the tls_container_id lengths in neutron.lbaas_sni
and octavia.sni tables.
2. Fixes the syntax error in cert_parser.py field. (tls_container.id => tls_container_id)
3. Removes the certs['sni_certs'] parameter from the rest_api_driver.py as it gets wrongly
assigned to socket_path parameter in the jinja_cfg.py file.
4. Modifies the sample_configs to make the unit tests work with the above changes.

Change-Id: I8fe5854ef2dc508e37a368294c44eef63b5bccba
Closes-Bug: #1520990
(cherry picked from commit 298fd45380a937f21f09a4532615fe3af139ab56)

commit_message:
L3 HA: Track qr and qg interfaces in keepalived

Currently, keepalived configure file doesn't track "qr"
or "qg" interfaces. VIP will not changed if "qr" or "qg"
inteface was down.

This patch will track these interfaces in keepalive configure
file. So that VIP will changed if "qr" or "qg" interface was down

Change-Id: I223651ae962075fe94aa23ee0842a6156c018add
Closes-Bug: #1605966

commit_message:
Add bgpvpn and speaker binding

This patch include following changes:
1. Add 'vpns' as attribution of bgp speaker
2. Add extension/db/plugin support for bgpvpn & speaker binging CLIs
   neutron bgp-speaker-vpn-add BGP_SPEAKER BGPVPN
   neutron bgp-speaker-vpn-remove BGP_SPEAKER BGPVPN
3. Add bgpvpn installation scripts for tox
4. Add flag "bgpvpn_enabled" in neutron.conf to indicate whether
   networking-bgpvpn is installed

Co-Authored-By: ruansx@cn.ibm.com

Change-Id: I08174a5ff103f2b975272211ea32f46fb7fffed2
Partial-Bug: #1509431

commit_message:
Update CIDR for subnet

Use case to solve: as an operator I want to expand or shrink Public
network without re-allocating all Floating IPs.

Generic approach is:

  1. Validate CIDR and gateway_ip. Regenerate allocation pools and
     gateway_ip for IPv6 PD if CIDR is changed.
  2. If new allocation pool is not provided, and old pool is not fit into
     CIDR, then fail. Same for new pool if provided.
  3. Re-allocate IP if they're out of new allocation pool.
  4. Notify routers that hold interfaces from Subnet.

Change-Id: I699815781198f92347b40330a0ca7d832fab7bb2
Closes-Bug: #1605343

commit_message:
Add some dhcp configuration options

This commit adds the following dhcp configuration options.
Such configurability helps to refactor the dhcp-agent to
be used only for metadata.

In Neutron
-------------

1) dhcp_rpc_callback
default:
"neutron.api.rpc.handlers.dhcp_rpc.DhcpRpcCallback"

2) dhcp_notifier
default:
"neutron.api.rpc.agentnotifiers.dhcp_rpc_agent_api.DhcpAgentNotifyAPI"

In DHCP Agent
-------------

3) dhcp_plugin_api
default:
"neutron.agent.dhcp.agent.DhcpPluginApi"

4) notifies_port_ready
default: True

Change-Id: If88e75d2f4b197c12a8618537b7169f9b6546989
Closes-Bug: 1611119

commit_message:
Replace "-C" to "--git-dir" in devstack/plugin.sh

The '-C' option is not available in the default git version
on CentOS.

Change-Id: Ia15d1785317c0f8b40c2b547250f402b58a34d18
Closes-Bug: #1611591

commit_message:
Enable Neutron for mutable-config

For an overview, see:

    http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.config/mutable.html

There are a few immediate benefits to doing this. 1) option
DEFAULT:debug becomes mutable; 2) log_config_append becomes mutable;
3) Neutron can make more options mutable as desired.

bp mutable-config-ocata

Change-Id: I53c3108c1fc923f1b00aecf6ea0116eae1b9597d

commit_message:
Set segments plugin as default

Before routed network, functions in [1] are used to manage
network segment. Routed network introduces a plugin [2] to manage
network segment. So, now there are 2 code paths to do the same job.
Except in ml2, the segments plugin will be used to manage network
segments.

Patch [3] [4] will make ml2 use segments plugin to create/delete segments.
This makes code simple and fixes the conflict issue mentioned in [4].
Since ml2 always uses segments, it brings the requirement to make segments
plugin always be available.

This patch sets the segments plugin as a default service plugin and
removes the code that checks if segments plugin is loaded.

[1] neutron.db.segments_db
[2] neutron.services.segments.plugin
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/317358/
[4] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/359147/

Change-Id: I535452ee8fb540e019393c6e570b321c3ad4ae0d

commit_message:
Fix serializer with None

Some neutron POST and PUT APIs don't return response body
but the JSONDictSerializer doesn't expect the None is passed.
This patch add a check for None into serializer.

Depends-On: Ia772927a28cb83c4c88680b5add925b12978dc5d
Change-Id: I6ee5f88ee518551f75416620750e0564945a42f8
Closes-Bug: #1555921
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/45/291545/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_serialize_none_data(self): """Test serialize with None as data.""" input_data = None content_type = 'application/json' serializer = wsgi.Serializer() result = serializer.serialize(input_data, content_type) self.assertIsNone(result)

commit_message:
Add BGP EVPN IP Prefix Advertisement support to Neutron Dynamic Routing

This spec proposes to advertise OpenStack tenant networks to upstream
(physical) routers running VPNs. The control plane uses BGP EVPN IP
Prefix Advertisement to advertise routes in the context of a typically
tenant-specific VPN. The corresponding data plane uses VXLAN on the
networks connecting OpenStack routers to upstream routers.

Change-Id: I78790f336b8531cc83e32076d395dce9615ee16e
Co-Authored-By: Siddanagouda Khot <siddanmk@yahoo.co.in>
Related-Bug: #1509431
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/54/322654/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============================================================================= Enhance Neutron Dynamic Routing with BGP EVPN IP prefix advertisement support ============================================================================= `[RFE] Enhance BGP Dynamic Routing with L2VPN/L3VPN support`_ .. _`[RFE] Enhance BGP Dynamic Routing with L2VPN/L3VPN support`: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1509431 Problem Description =================== In `Neutron Dynamic Routing`_, on behalf of an OpenStack region, BGP Speakers advertise external reachability information to upstream (physical) routers. Neutron Dynamic Routing alleviates the need to provision upstream routers whenever reachable subnets or floating IP addresses are added. In a public data center environment, Neutron Dynamic Routing is limited to Internet reachability, since the base BGP protocol only supports a single IP address scope. For some tenants, access to the public Internet is not enough. They may have networks connecting OpenStack routers to upstream upstream (physical) routers running VPNs. There are many possible reasons to connect to upstream tenant-specific VPNs, including: 1. Connectivity to an on premises tenant site using L3VPN connectivity, similar to AWS DirectConnect or SoftLayer DirectLink 2. Connectivity between OpenStack regions, either for geographic diversity or due to specific services available in specific OpenStack regions (e.g. bare metal support) 3. Connectivity to a non-OpenStack public data center The goal of this effort is to advertise OpenStack tenant networks to upstream (physical) routers via VPN routes. Using a dynamic routing protocol, IP prefixes should be advertised to upstream (physical) routers whenever reachable subnets are added, in the context of a (typically tenant-specific) VPN with a (typically tenant-specific) address scope. Proposed Change =============== This enhancement adds support for BGP EVPN prefix advertisement, extending the scope of Neutron Dynamic Routing. BGP Speakers advertise addresses reachable within OpenStack along with the appropriate BGP EVPN context to upstream physical routers. This solution is based on the `IP Prefix Advertisement in EVPN`_ IETF draft, an emerging standard for exchange of reachability information in the form of IP address prefixes. This is a good fit for OpenStack deployments that include tenant routers controlled by OpenStack connecting to upstream physical routers that lie outside of OpenStacks control. The data plane will use the VXLAN encapsulation on the networks connecting OpenStack to the outside world, since VXLAN is a widely implemented standard in both hardware and software. VXLAN is already supported by several OpenStack implementations, including the ML2 with L3 plugin / L3 agent reference implementation, and OVN. Through the combination of BGP EVPNs with VXLAN, we can implement the necessary L3VPN functionality without incurring the complexity of MPLS L3VPNs. The upstream physical routers can convert from BGP EVPN to MPLS L3VPNs, if desired. The intention is to leverage both the `Neutron Dynamic Routing`_ and `BGPVPN`_ frameworks, bringing aspects of both together along with the addition of support for BGP EVPN prefix advertisement. The initial implementation will support the OVN data plane. For OVN, the EVPN Route Type 5 (IP Prefix route) advertisements will contain host routes, since different endpoints in the same subnet may reside on different compute nodes and thus need different underlay IPs (specified in the BGP next hop field). This is similar to the issue addressed by `[RFE] DVR-aware fixed IP announcements for with BGP`_, which will advertise fixed IPs as host routes, where the next hop IP address is associated with the FIP instance on the compute node where the fixed IP resides. BGP EVPN Prefix Advertisement Route Types ----------------------------------------- The `IP Prefix Advertisement in EVPN`_ IETF draft includes numerous route types that can be used in various ways, allowing for different solutions targeting different scenarios to be satisfied using the most appropriate route type(s). The proposed implementation will use EVPN Route Type 5 (EVPN IP Prefix Route) that specifies: +-----------------------------------+------------------------------------+ | RD (8 octets) | | +-----------------------------------+------------------------------------+ | Ethernet Segment Identifier | set to 0 | | (10 octets) | | +-----------------------------------+------------------------------------+ | Ethernet Tag ID (4 octets) | set to 0 | +-----------------------------------+------------------------------------+ | IP Prefix Length (1 octet) | | +-----------------------------------+------------------------------------+ | IP Prefix (4 or 16 octets) | | +-----------------------------------+------------------------------------+ | GW IP Address (4 or 16 octets) | set to 0 | +-----------------------------------+------------------------------------+ | MPLS Label (3 octets) | set to the VNI value | +-----------------------------------+------------------------------------+ | Router's MAC Extended Community | set to the inner destination MAC | | | (of the Neutron router) | +-----------------------------------+------------------------------------+ | BGP Encapsulation Extended | set Tunnel-type = VXLAN | | Community | | +-----------------------------------+------------------------------------+ | Next hop field of the | set to the underlay IP | | MP_REACH_NLRI | | +-----------------------------------+------------------------------------+ The reason to go with GW IP and ESI both set to 0 is to avoid the need to assign (per node, per external network) or (per node, per router) IP and MAC addresses, while retaining the capability to direct traffic from the outside world directly towards the appropriate compute node through the BGP next hop field that specifies the underlay IP. With this approach, since all of the information is included in a single Route Type 5 advertisement, the inner destination MAC must be included. Design ------ This implementation will use VPN information maintained in BGPVPN (with an additional VNI field) and the BGP Speaker information maintained in Neutron Dynamic Routing to generate the EVPN IP prefix route type 5 updates. In order to associate a VPN to a BGP Speaker, a new ``BgpSpeakerVPNbinding`` table containing ``bgpvpnid`` and ``bgp_speaker_id`` will be maintained in the Neutron DB. The user creates a record in this table after configuring a VPN in BGPVPN and a BGP Speaker in Neutron Dynamic Routing. Once this record is created, based on the events mentioned below, VPN and route information is pushed to the DRAgent and in turn to the BGP Speaker. The following conditions need to be met: * BGP Speaker to VPN association * VPN to Neutron router association * Neutron router should have a network with VPN VNI * Address scope of the new subnet to match the VPN VNI network Architecture ^^^^^^^^^^^^ .. blockdiag:: blockdiag { class plugin[height=120]; class agent[width=280]; class driver[width=130]; node_width=200; node_height=50; span_width=50; group { orientation=portrait label="BGPVPN"; color=lightblue; VPNPlugin[label="BGPVPN Plugin/DB/Extensions"]; VPNDriver[label="BGPVPN DR Service Driver"]; VPNPlugin -> VPNDriver [dir=none]; } group { label="Neutron Dynamic Routing"; color=lightgreen; Plugin[class="plugin", label="Dynamic Routing Plugin"]; DB[label="Dynamic Routing Database"]; Extensions[label="Dynamic Routing Extensions"]; Scheduler[label="Dynamic Routing Agent Scheduler"]; Plugin -> DB, Extensions, Scheduler [dir=none]; } group { orientation=portrait label="Dynamic Routing Agent"; color=orange; Agent[class="agent", label="Dynamic Routing Agent"]; DMgr[class="agent", label="Driver Manager"]; DAPI[class="agent", label="Common Driver API"]; Quagga[class="driver", label="Quagga Driver"]; Drivers[class="driver", label="Other Drivers", stacked]; Agent -> DMgr -> DAPI -> Quagga, Drivers [dir=none]; } VPNDriver -> Plugin [dir=none, label="RPC", folded]; Plugin -> Agent [dir=none, label="RPC", folded]; } Leveraging Neutron Dynamic Routing ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ This implementation will leverage existing Neutron Dynamic Routing constructs including the APIs and extensions, plugin, database, DRAgent, DRAgent scheduler, RPC between the plugin and the DRAgent, and the driver interface. One aspect of Neutron Dynamic Routing that will not be used for BGP EVPN solution is the association of gateway networks with BGP speakers, along with the ``BgpSpeakerNetworkBinding`` DB class. The assumption is that the gateway network associations will continue to be used to indicate a desire to advertise the corresponding routes in base (non-EVPN) BGP4. Instead, the new ``BgpSpeakerVPNbinding`` class described above will drive advertisement of VPN routes. In order to support this, some existing Neutron Dynamic Routing constructs will need to be enhanced. In the plugin, the following system events will be handled: * Router interface creation/deletion * Subnet pool change address scope * VM creation/deletion or VM port up/down When these system events occur, they will drive advertisement and withdrawal of VPN routes to the DRAgent. The plugin and DB mixin will execute DB queries, using a similar approach as in existing Neutron Dynamic Routing, but extending across different tables in Neutron, Neutron Dynamic Routing, and BGPVPN. In addition, the plugin will act as a relay, passing announcement/withdrawal of new bgpvpns (including RD, RT, VNI) to the DRAgent. New RPC functions will be added. For VPN routes, RPCs for advertisement and withdrawal of BGP routes will specify a VNI field on each route. Similarly, the driver interface will also specify a VNI field on each VPN route. The BGP speaker (e.g. Quagga) will use the VNI value to associate the route with a specific VPN. Leveraging BGPVPN ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ BGPVPN holds the VPN information. Updates happening to the VPN record will be notified to Neutron Dynamic Routing. The following notifications from BGPVPN will be used: 1. Add/update/delete of bgpvpn record (post commit) 2. bgpvpn to router (in bgpvpn) association/removal (post commit) 3. Get bgpvpn record/records A service driver will be added for communication between BGPVPN and Neutron Dynamic Routing. These will communicate with each other via RPC to push/pull information. Data Model Impact ----------------- The following table will be added to the Neutron database. CRUD functions will be added to update the records in the table. 1. ``BgpSpeakerVPNbindings`` - Table to associate bgpvpn and bgp speaker. REST API Impact --------------- New APIs ^^^^^^^^ A new API (corresponding to the new ``BgpSpeakerVPNbindings`` DB class) is needed in order to associate BGPVPNs with BGP Speakers. Since the notion of a BGP Speaker is specific to Neutron Dynamic Routing, the new API and DB class will be defined in Neutron Dynamic Routing. Once a specific BGPVPN has been associated with a specific BGP Speaker, all routes for that BGPVPN (determined based on the specified BGPVPN Router Associations) will be advertised by that BGP Speaker. Leveraging Neutron Dynamic Routing APIs ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ The existing ``/bgp-speakers``, ``/bgp-peers``, ``/bgp-speakers/%s/add_bgp_peer``, and ``/bgp-speakers/%s/remove_bgp_peer`` APIs will be reused directly for BGP EVPN functionality. Correspondingly, the ``BgpSpeaker``, ``BgpPeer``, and ``BgpSpeakerPeerBinding`` DB classes will be reused directly. However, the ``/bgp-speakers/%s/add_gateway_network`` and ``/bgp-speakers/%s/remove_gateway_network`` APIs (and correspondingly the ``BgpSpeakerNetworkBinding`` DB class) will not apply to BGP EVPN functionality, since it does not put the network in the context of any specific VPN. These APIs will continue to be used to drive the routes associated with base (non-EVPN) BGP4 functionality. Leveraging BGPVPN APIs ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ APIs and DB classes have already been defined in the networking-bgpvpn project for BGPVPN CRUD, and to associate routers with BGPVPNs. These APIs and DB classes will be used directly for BGP EVPN functionality. Specifically the ``/bgpvpns`` and ``/bgpvpns/%s/router_associations`` APIs (and correspondingly the ``BGPVPN`` and ``BGPVPNRouterAssociation`` DB classes) will be used directly for BGP EVPN functionality. Neutron Dynamic Routing will have an optional dependency on BGPVPN, in order to enable BGP EVPN functionality. If BGPVPN is not configured, then any attempt to create a BGPVPN or to create a BGP Speaker to BGPVPN Association will fail. Security Impact --------------- This feature will allow an external system to manipulate routing information within Neutron network. The external system should be trusted and may be authenticated using a shared secret. Dynamic routing may only be configured by the system administrator. Notifications Impact -------------------- A notification should be provided when connectivity of control channel over which routes are exchanged is interrupted. Other End User Impact --------------------- Following CLI commands will be added to the neutron client: 1. ``bgp-speaker-vpn-create`` 2. ``bgp-speaker-vpn-delete`` 3. ``bgp-speaker-vpn-list`` Performance and Scale Impact ---------------------------- This should be similar to existing Neutron Dynamic Routing. With BGP EVPN, each BGP speaker can advertise information for many different VPNs in each adjacency, so this implementation should be able to support a large number of VPNs without any significant performance impact. IPv6 Impact ----------- This implementation will support both IPv4 and IPv6. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- In order to use BGP EVPN functionality, both Neutron Dynamic and BGPVPN must be explicitly enabled and configured. Dependencies ============ The new BGP EVPN functionality in Neutron Dynamic Routing will have an installation dependency on BGPVPN. For users who are not interested in EVPN functionality, Neutron Dynamic Routing will continue to operate as is, even if BGPVPN is not installed. In order to set up the VXLAN tunnels to the upstream physical routers, there is a dependency on the functionality suggested in either `[RFE] Add support for external vxlan encapsulation to neutron router`_ or `[RFE] Add BGP Listener Support to BGP Dynamic Routing with VPN, for Dynamic Separation of Internet and Tenant External Traffic`_. Either of these could provide the information necessary to set up the corresponding VXLAN tunnels. Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- Tempest Tests for BGP EVPN functionality will be added. Functional Tests ---------------- Functional Tests for BGP EVPN functionality will be added. API Tests --------- Tests will be added for the new API for BGP EVPN functionality. Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ User documentation will be provided to: * Explain BGP EVPN functionality * New APIs and CLIs * Explain relationship with existing Neutron Dynamic Routing and BGPVPN functionality * Examples * Installation dependencies Developer Documentation ----------------------- Refer to the Neutron Dynamic Routing developer documentation. References ========== .. target-notes:: .. _`Neutron Dynamic Routing`: http:///docs.openstack.org/mitaka/networking-guide/adv-config-bgp-dynamic-routing.html .. _`BGPVPN`: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/networking-bgpvpn/ .. _`IP Prefix Advertisement in EVPN`: https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-bess-evpn-prefix-advertisement-02 .. _`[RFE] Add support for external vxlan encapsulation to neutron router`: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1525059 .. _`[RFE] Add BGP Listener Support to BGP Dynamic Routing with VPN, for Dynamic Separation of Internet and Tenant External Traffic`: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1509436 .. _`[RFE] DVR-aware fixed IP announcements for with BGP`: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1585770

commit_message:
Don't include [agent] section in neutron.conf.sample

neutron-server does not need options from the [agent] section so remove
this section from the neutron.conf.sample config file.

Change-Id: I589c8c67415d2e5d0550251e6175987a3aa90633
Closes-Bug: #1620211

subject: Add config option for L3 address scope
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-17 09:14:32.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/tests/unit/agent/l3/test_router_info.py', 'neutron/agent/l3/router_info.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/agent/l3/test_agent.py', 'neutron/agent/l3/dvr_edge_router.py', 'neutron/conf/agent/l3/config.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/aae5b39992f3b040fdb500259acc10653d003e43', 'message': 'Add config option for L3 address scope

In general, we may not use address scope function, but IPtables
rules for address scope always initialized and processed in router
update.

We can add a config option for address scope, IPtables rules for
address scope will not handle if we disable address scope.

DocImpact
UpgradeImpact

commit_message:
Add config option for L3 address scope

In general, we may not use address scope function, but IPtables
rules for address scope always initialized and processed in router
update.

We can add a config option for address scope, IPtables rules for
address scope will not handle if we disable address scope.

DocImpact
UpgradeImpact

Change-Id: Ie8ec19f9062e562a9e15533e78c316e4c4d6e19f
Closes-Bug: #1613642
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/29/356329/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Allow deletion of ERRORed load balancers

The API was not allowing the deletion of load balancers in ERROR state.
Users should be able to delete their load balancers in ACTIVE or ERROR
state.  This is good for users and good for operators.

Closes-Bug: #1607502

Conflicts:
	octavia/tests/functional/db/test_repositories.py

Change-Id: If1587e25d5f79c136d3aec4e129a8227dddbce3f

Fix KeyError in get_isolated_subnets

commit_message:
Allow easy configuration of host/port settings

The monascastatsd client allowed the host and port to be set but only if you
constructed a Connection object yourself.  This allows you just to specify
host and port when constructing the client object.

Change-Id: Ib49e261b915c07bf8f7036164f1e4814d80ecc1f

deleted_lines: def __init__(self, name=None, connection=None, max_buffer_size=50, dimensions=None): if connection is None: self.connection = Connection(host='localhost', port=8125, max_buffer_size=50)

commit_message:
Add dogtag-pki and python-nss as extra requirement

dogtag imports pki so mention it as requirement. python-nss
is needed by dogtag-pki.
Also add a bindep.txt file which is used by bindep to install system
packages.
To install python-nss via pip, header files from nss-devel and
mozilla-nss-devel are needed.

Change-Id: Ia3276ad4be56d40fddbf458f215ab93e44ed6907
Depends-On: Ibedae54e631e9c3d3726453adcd204ce96b19d77
Closes-Bug: #1604417

commit_message:
Add filters provider-* to the network proxy networks() method

Add query parameters provider-network-type, provider-physical-network
and provider-segment to the network proxy networks() method.

Change-Id: Idf5b7f804b6ecd6ac51aa442c17d0ff6752cfc97
Partial-bug: #1635580
Partially-Implements: blueprint network-command-sdk-support

added_lines: * ``provider:network_type``: Network physical mechanism * ``provider:physical_network``: Physical network * ``provider:segmentation_id``: VLAN ID for VLAN networks or Tunnel ID for GENEVE/GRE/VXLAN networks

subject: Add login shell for user nova on Centos for live migration
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-10-19 05:48:38.000000000', 'files': ['deployment/puppet/openstack_tasks/manifests/roles/compute.pp'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/83299ba7bf4bafa12ef64fe40dfb4b927d9c9eb9', 'message': 'Add login shell for user nova on Centos for live migration

To live migrate, user nova has to ssh to another compute node, so user
nova should have a login shell, but rpm install process creates user
nova does not have a login shell.
[root@node-52 ~]# cat /etc/passwd | grep nova
nova:x:162:162:OpenStack Nova Daemons:/var/lib/nova:/sbin/nologin

Change-Id: I4ee987a28378300dbbad296de52a807c1436b56e
'}]
commit_message:
Add login shell for user nova on Centos for live migration

To live migrate, user nova has to ssh to another compute node, so user
nova should have a login shell, but rpm install process creates user
nova does not have a login shell.
[root@node-52 ~]# cat /etc/passwd | grep nova
nova:x:162:162:OpenStack Nova Daemons:/var/lib/nova:/sbin/nologin

Change-Id: I4ee987a28378300dbbad296de52a807c1436b56e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/96/388396/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # To live migrate, user nova has to ssh to another compute node, so user nova should # have a login shell, but rpm install process creates user nova don't have a login shell if $::osfamily == 'RedHat' { user { 'nova': name => 'nova', ensure => 'present', shell => '/bin/bash', } }

commit_message:
Remove the Stress framework

It's not used anymore. There was general consensus in Feb 2016
to deprecate it (see [1]) and remove it in Newton.

[1]  [qa] deprecating Tempest stress framework

Change-Id: Ib229985ea2a1fee495c9492c9ce1781e6bac1dc6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/88/380988/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def stresstest(**kwargs): """Add stress test decorator For all functions with this decorator a attr stress will be set automatically. @param class_setup_per: allowed values are application, process, action ``application``: once in the stress job lifetime ``process``: once in the worker process lifetime ``action``: on each action @param allow_inheritance: allows inheritance of this attribute """ def decorator(f): if 'class_setup_per' in kwargs: setattr(f, "st_class_setup_per", kwargs['class_setup_per']) else: setattr(f, "st_class_setup_per", 'process') if 'allow_inheritance' in kwargs: setattr(f, "st_allow_inheritance", kwargs['allow_inheritance']) else: setattr(f, "st_allow_inheritance", False) attr(type='stress')(f) return f return decorator

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/training-guides refs/changes/03/390203/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ======================= OpenStack Documentation ======================= .. image:: ./_assets/os_background.png :class: fill :width: 100% Mission ======= Provide documentation for core OpenStack projects to promote OpenStack. Develop and maintain tools and processes to ensure quality, accurate documentation. Treat documentation like OpenStack code. Sites ===== - http://docs.openstack.org - http://developer.openstack.org Specialty teams =============== - API - Configuration Reference and CLI Reference - High Availability Guide - Hypervisor Tuning Guide - Installation guides - Networking Guide - Operations and Architecture Design guides - Security Guide - Training guides - Training labs - User guides Repositories ============ - docs-specs - openstack-doc-tools - openstack-manuals - openstackdocstheme - security-doc - training-guides - training-labs Bug reports =========== - https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-manuals - https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-api-site Contributor guide ================= - http://docs.openstack.org/contributor-guide/index.html This guide provides detailed instructions on the contribution workflow and conventions to be considered by all documentation contributors. Building documentation ====================== - http://docs.openstack.org/contributor-guide/docs-builds.html

commit_message:
VMAX driver - Update documentation for SE hotfix

Updating documentation to reflect a Solution Enabler hotfix
on 8.3. All occurrences of SE8.3 are now SE8.3.0.1. SSL
section also updated for accuracy and clarity.

Change-Id: I7038124f36b1cc646327ab07fd7cda86bdefab7d
Closes-Bug: #1633041
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/45/386045/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: For VMAX-3 series, Solutions Enabler 8.3.0.1 is required. This is SSL only. VMAX All Flash array with Solutions Enabler 8.3.0.1 have compression enabled by default when associated with Diamond Service Level. This means volumes added to any newly created storage groups will be compressed. The ECOM component in Solutions Enabler enforces SSL in 8.3.0.1. By default, this port is 5989. #. Get the CA certificate of the ECOM server. This pulls the CA cert file and saves it as .pem file. ``my_ecom_host`` is the ip address or hostname of the ECOM server. ``ca_cert.pem`` is the sample name of the .pem: # openssl s_client -showcerts -connect my_ecom_host:5989 </dev/null 2>/dev/null|openssl x509 -outform PEM >ca_cert.pem # cp ca_cert.pem /usr/share/ca-certificates/ca_cert.crt adding the following to the back end block. ``my_location`` is the location of the .pem file generated in step 1.: driver_ssl_cert_path = /my_location/ca_cert.pem (Optional if Step 2 and 3 are skipped)
deleted_lines: For VMAX-3 series, Solutions Enabler 8.3 is required. This is SSL only. VMAX All Flash array with Solutions Enabler 8.3 have compression enabled by default when associated with Diamond Service Level. This means volumes added to any newly created storage groups will be compressed. The ECOM component in Solutions Enabler enforces SSL in 8.3. By default, this port is 5989. #. Get the CA certificate of the ECOM server: # openssl s_client -showcerts -connect <ecom_hostname>.lss.emc.com:5989 </dev/null # cp <ecom_hostname>.lss.emc.com.pem /usr/share/ca-certificates/<ecom_hostname>.lss.emc.com.crt adding the following to the back end block: driver_ssl_cert_path = /opt/stack/<ecom_hostname>.lss.emc.com.pem (Optional if Step 3 and 4 are skipped)

commit_message:
Updating Kaminario Cinder drivers manual

Change-Id: I1f726bb08907ae7d75ea2cc48fcc5987c902dd8a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/15/388615/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================================================ Kaminario K2 Block Storage Driver Configuration ================================================ The high performance Kaminario K2 All Flash Array offers Block Storage services to OpenStack. Using the driver, OpenStack Block Storage hosts can connect to one or more K2 storage arrays. This documentation explains how to configure and connect the block storage nodes to one or more K2 Storage Array systems.- K2 version 5.8 and later are supported. - ``krest`` version 1.3.1 (or later) python library should be installed on the Block Storage node using :command:`sudo pip install krest` - In order to perform the following operations, the Block Storage Node must have a data path to the K2 array: - Retype dedup to nodedup and vice versa Limitations and known issues ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ If you do not set up your deployment to use multipath, the network connectivity of the array will use a single physical port. This may significantly limit the available bandwidth and the high-availability and non-disruptive upgrade benefits provided by K2. To enjoy these benefits, make sure you have multipath access on Compute and Block Storage Node. - Install Multipath Software on both Compute and Block Storage. Example: - Ubuntu 14.04 - ``sudo apt-get install --yes sg3-utils multipath-tools`` - In ``libvirt`` section of the ``nova.conf`` file, specify ``iscsi_use_multipath=True`` . This option is valid for both iSCSI and FC drivers. Additional resources: Kaminario Host Configuration Guide for Linux (for configuring multipath) - After adding above option in the ``nova.conf`` file, restart the Compute services for the changes to take effect. The following command is usually used for restarting the Compute service: .. code-block:: console $ service nova-compute restart~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ - Create/Delete/Attach/Detach Volume - Create/Delete Snapshot - Create Volume from Snapshot/Image/Clone - Create Image from Volume - Volume extend - Volume retype - Manage/Un-manage Volume - Replicate volume to a secondary K2 array. Kaminario K2 Block Storage driver configuration ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ This section details the steps to be followed for configuring the Kaminario Cinder Driver for FC or iSCSI. This procedure refers to the configuration of a single back-end. In case of multiple back-ends, please refer to the ``Setting multiple K2 back-end storage systems`` section below. - Open the cinder.conf file for editing . The configuration file is usually located under the following path /etc/cinder/cinder.conf. - Under the [DEFAULT] section, in the enabled_backends parameter do one of the following: - For an FC back-end, enter: enabled_backends = kaminario-fc-1 - For an iSCSI back-end, enter: enabled_backends = kaminario-iscsi-1 .. code-block:: ini [DEFAULT] enabled_backends = kaminario-iscsi-1 - Under the [DEFAULT] section,add the following filters in the scheduler_default_filters parameter ``scheduler_default_filters = DriverFilter,CapabilitiesFilter`` The DriverFilter filters hosts based on a 'filter function' and metrics while the CapabilitiesFilter filters hosts based on resource (instance & volume) type records. - Create a new section (in addition to the [DEFAULT] section) using the name used in the ``enabled_backends`` parameter (e.g. [kaminario-iscsi-1]). .. code-block:: ini [kaminario-iscsi-1] - In the newly created back-end section (e.g. [kaminario-iscsi-1]), set the following configuration options: .. list-table:: **Configuration options in cinder.conf** :header-rows: 1 * - Option - Values - Description * - ``volume_driver`` - Enter one of the following: For FC: - ``cinder.volume.drivers.kaminario.kaminario_fc.KaminarioFCDriver`` For iSCSI: - ``cinder.volume.drivers.kaminario.kaminario_iscsi.KaminarioISCSIDriver`` - The path to the code of K2s volume driver. * - ``volume_backend_name`` - String - A user defined name for a back-end storage volume. The name will be used when defining volume types, in order to relate the volume type to the specific back-end storage. * - ``auto_calc_max_oversubscription_ratio`` - False (default)  uses the default value of x20. True  calculates the reduction rate based on the existing data - Thin provisioning settings * - ``san_ip`` - IP address - The management IP for the K2 back-end storage system. * - ``san_login`` - The user name for accessing the K2 back-end storage system. For example, "admin". - User credentials - K2 user name * - ``san_password`` - The password as defined for the admin. - User credentials - K2 password. * - ``use_multipath_for_image_xfer`` - True (recommend) - Use initiator multipath option. * - ``replication_device`` - In order to perform replication, the replication_device parameter must be configured with the following attributes: - backend_id - replication target MGMT IP - login - replication target username - password - replication target password - rpo - replication recovery point objective in seconds Example: replication_device = backend_id:10.0.0.50,login:user1,password:1234,rpo:300 ``Note``: the RPO must be either 60 (1 min) or multiples of 300 (5 min) The replication peer must be configured on the primary and the secondary K2 arrays. - replication target device * - ``surpress_requests_ssl_warnings`` - True - Suppress requests library SSL certificate warnings. * - ``filter_function`` - "capabilities.total_volumes < 250" - Set a limit on total number of volumes that will be created on the K2 array. .. code-block:: ini [kaminario-iscsi-1] volume_driver = cinder.volume.drivers.kaminario.kaminario_iscsi.KaminarioISCSIDriver volume_backend_name = kaminario-iscsi san_ip = 172.16.50.47 san_login = admin san_password = admin replication_device = backend_id:172.16.50.47,login:admin,password:admin,rpo:300 - After adding option groups in the cinder.conf file, restart the cinder volume services for the changes to take effect. The following command is usually used for restarting the cinder volume service: .. code-block:: console $ service cinder-volume restart Setting multiple K2 back-end storage systems ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ This section details the steps to be followed for configuring the multiple K2 systems. Each K2 system is directly connected to OpenStack. To configure multiple K2s: - Modify the [DEFAULT] section of the cinder.conf file to add an enabled_backends parameter specifying the names of back-end system types you wish to add, separated by comas. Each back-end system should be numbered consecutively. ``enabled_backends = kaminario-fc1, kaminario-fc2, kaminario-fc3`` - Add a Back-end group section for each back-end you wish to add. - For each back-end group, enter the configuration options as described in step 3 in the Kaminario K2 Block Storage driver configuration procedure above. Note that several back ends may have the same volume_backend_name. In this case, the scheduler will decide which back-end to use for the creation of the volume. The name of the back-end is declared as an extra-specification of a volume type (such as, volume_backend_name=LVM). When a volume is created, the scheduler chooses an appropriate back end to handle the request, according to the volume type specified by the user. See `<http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide/blockstorage-multi-backend.html>`_ for additional information. - After adding all the option groups in the cinder.conf file, restart the cinder volume services for the changes to take effect. The following command is usually used for restarting the cinder volume service: .. code-block:: console $ service cinder-volume restart Creating volume typesOnce the ``cinder.conf`` has been updated and the cinder volume service has been restarted, cinder commands need to be issued in order to create and associate OpenStack volume types with the declared ``volume_backend_names``. The Volume back-end names can be any user defined name. For each volume type, you should specify an attribute that will determine if the volume type includes deduplication and/or replication. The system includes the following default settings: - Deduplication is enabled - Replication is disabled For example, the following command is used to create a dedup volume type: .. code-block:: console $ cinder type-create kaminario-d $ cinder type-key kaminario-d set volume_backend_name = <volume_backend_name> The following command is used to create a non-dedup volume type: .. code-block:: console $ cinder type-create kaminario-nd $ cinder type-key kaminario-nd set volume_backend_name=<volume_backend_name> kaminario:thin_prov_type=nodedup The following command is used to create a dedup volume with replication: .. code-block:: console $ cinder type-create kaminario-d-rep $ cinder type-key kaminario-d-rep set volume_backend_name=<volume_backend_name> kaminario:replication=enabled The following command is used to create a non-dedup volume with replication: .. code-block:: console $ cinder type-create kaminario-nd-rep1. $ cinder type-key kaminario-nd-rep set volume_backend_name=<volume_backend_name> kaminario:thin_prov_type=nodedup kaminario:replication=enabled By issuing these commands, the Block Storage volume types kaminario-d, kaminario-nd, kaminario-d-rep and kaminario-nd-rep are associated with the kaminario-iscsi backends.
deleted_lines: ========================================================================= Kaminario K2 all-flash array iSCSI and FC OpenStack Block Storage drivers ========================================================================= Kaminario's K2 all-flash array leverages a unique software-defined architecture that delivers highly valued predictable performance, scalability and cost-efficiency. Kaminario's K2 all-flash iSCSI and FC arrays can be used in OpenStack Block Storage for providing block storage using ``KaminarioISCSIDriver`` class and ``KaminarioFCDriver`` class respectively.- Kaminario's K2 all-flash iSCSI and/or FC array - K2 REST API version >= 2.2.0 - ``krest`` python library should be installed on the Block Storage node using :command:`sudo pip install krest` - The Block Storage Node should also have a data path to the K2 array for the following operations: - Retype 'dedup without replication'<->'nodedup without replication'- Create, delete, attach, and detach volumes. - Create and delete volume snapshots. - Create a volume from a snapshot. - Copy an image to a volume. - Copy a volume to an image. - Clone a volume. - Extend a volume. - Retype a volume. - Manage and unmanage a volume. - Replicate volume with failover and failback support to K2 array. Configure Kaminario iSCSI/FC back end ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ #. Edit the ``/etc/cinder/cinder.conf`` file and define a configuration group for iSCSI/FC back end. .. code-block:: ini [DEFAULT] enabled_backends = kaminario # Use DriverFilter in combination of other filters to use 'filter_function' # scheduler_default_filters = DriverFilter,CapabilitiesFilter [kaminario] # Management IP of Kaminario K2 All-Flash iSCSI/FC array san_ip = 10.0.0.10 # Management username of Kaminario K2 All-Flash iSCSI/FC array san_login = username # Management password of Kaminario K2 All-Flash iSCSI/FC array san_password = password # Enable Kaminario K2 iSCSI/FC driver volume_driver = cinder.volume.drivers.kaminario.kaminario_iscsi.KaminarioISCSIDriver # volume_driver = cinder.volume.drivers.kaminario.kaminario_fc.KaminarioFCDriver # Backend name volume_backend_name = kaminario # K2 driver calculates max_oversubscription_ratio on setting below # option as True. Default value is False # auto_calc_max_oversubscription_ratio = False # Set a limit on total number of volumes to be created on K2 array, for example: # filter_function = "capabilities.total_volumes < 250" # For replication, replication_device must be set and the replication peer must be configured # on the primary and the secondary K2 arrays # Syntax: # replication_device = backend_id:<s-array-ip>,login:<s-username>,password:<s-password>,rpo:<value> # where: # s-array-ip is the secondary K2 array IP # rpo must be either 60(1 min) or multiple of 300(5 min) # Example: # replication_device = backend_id:10.0.0.50,login:kaminario,password:kaminario,rpo:300 # Suppress requests library SSL certificate warnings on setting this option as True # Default value is 'False' # suppress_requests_ssl_warnings = False #. Save the changes to the ``/etc/cinder/cinder.conf`` file and restart the ``cinder-volume`` service. Driver options ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The following table contains the configuration options that are specific to the Kaminario K2 FC and iSCSI Block Storage drivers. .. include:: ../../tables/cinder-kaminario.rst

commit_message:
Update description of CP in VNFD Template Guide

Descripton of Connection Point needs to be updated to keep
consistency with tacker_nfv_defs.yaml.
Currently 'type' is an optional property and has a constraint.
Also 'security_groups' property was introduced in [1].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/334256/

Change-Id: Ic0721c3914197bdc7128b5fff76783a2f7ba9f9e

A CP always requires a virtual link and a virtual binding associated with it. anti_spoofing_protection: false security_groups: - secgroup1 - secgroup2 anti_spoofing_protection: false| type | No |String | One of | Specifies the type | | | | | | of CP | | | | | - vnic | | | | | | - sriov | || security_groups | No |List | None | List of security | | | | | | groups to be | | | | | | associated with | | | | | | the CP | +-------------------------+--------+-------+-----------+----------------------+ security_groups: list of security groups
deleted_lines: virtual link. It may be a virtual port, a virtual NIC address, a physical port or a physical NIC address. Each connection point has to bind to a VDU. A CP always requires a virtual link and a virtual binding associated with it. anti_spoof_protection: false anti_spoof_protection: false| type | Yes |String | None | Could be anything | | | | | | like virtual port, | | | | | | virtual NIC address, | | | | | | physical port, | | | | | | physical NIC address |

This adds the implementation for get_instance_diagnostics method.

With nova-powervm, as opposed to the other drivers, the disk details in
the instance diagnostics actually refer to the storage adapter details.
That is because, we put many disks on a given storage bus.
And because of that, we can only get the diagnostics for the storage bus.

commit_message:
WIP: PowerVM: Implement get_instance_diagnostics

This adds the implementation for get_instance_diagnostics method.

With nova-powervm, as opposed to the other drivers, the disk details in
the instance diagnostics actually refer to the storage adapter details.
That is because, we put many disks on a given storage bus. And because
of that, we can only get the diagnostics for the storage bus.

Change-Id: I7e509b8247b8133529acff5ef10f9341e62f0c93
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm refs/changes/25/350525/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.virt import diagnosticsfrom oslo_utils import timeutils def get_instance_diagnostics(self, instance): """Retrieve diagnostics for the given instance.""" config_drive = configdrive.required_by(instance) launched_at = timeutils.normalize_time(instance['launched_at']) uptime = timeutils.delta_seconds(launched_at, timeutils.utcnow()) state = 'To-Do' diags = diagnostics.Diagnostics(state=state, driver='powervm', config_drive=config_drive, hypervisor_os='powervm', uptime=uptime) lpar_uuid = vm.get_pvm_uuid(instance) # Get the latest lpar metrics from cache. # To-Do(kotra03): Define metric_cache and initialize it. date, lpar_metrics = metric_cache.get_latest_metric(lpar_uuid) # If there are no metrics returned for lpar, then just return # with the existing minimal diagnostics data. if lpar_metrics is None: return diags # Add memory diagnostics lpar_memory_metrics = lpar_metrics.memory if lpar_memory_metrics is not None: total_mem = lpar_memory_metrics.logical_mem free_mem = total_mem * \ lpar_memory_metrics.pct_real_mem_free / 100.0 diags.memory_details.maximum = int(round(total_mem)) diags.memory_details.used = int(round(total_mem - free_mem)) # Add processor diagnostics # Ideally per vCPU cpu times. # However, powervm does not provide vcpu level granularity metrics. # So, provide overall time taken by CPU for executing # the instructions. lpar_proc_metrics = lpar_metrics.processor if lpar_proc_metrics is not None: cpu_time = lpar_proc_metrics.total_inst_exec_time diags.add_cpu(time=cpu_time) # Add network diagnostics lpar_network_metrics = lpar_metrics.network if lpar_network_metrics is not None: # Get the Client VM's Network Adapters client_cnas = vm.get_cnas(self.adapter, instance) for metric_cna in lpar_network_metrics.cnas: # Get the MAC address for cna mac = None for client_cna in client_cnas: if client_cna.loc_code == metric_cna.physical_location: mac = vm.norm_mac(client_cna.mac) break if mac is None: continue # PowerVM does not provide rx_errors, rx_drop, tx_errors # and tx_drop details. Those properties will default to '0'. # Let us add to the diagnostics the rest of the details that # are available. diags.add_nic(mac_address=mac, rx_octets=metric_cna.received_bytes, rx_packets=metric_cna.received_packets, tx_octets=metric_cna.sent_bytes, tx_packets=metric_cna.sent_packets) # Add disk_details # Note: PowerVM provides adapter details instead of disk details. lpar_storage_metrics = lpar_metrics.storage if lpar_storage_metrics is not None: # Bundle together the SCSI and virtual FC adapters adpts = lpar_storage_metrics.virt_adpts + \ lpar_storage_metrics.vfc_adpts # Loop through all the storage adapters for adpt in adpts: diags.add_disk(id=adpt.name, read_bytes=adpt.read_bytes, read_requests=adpt.num_reads, write_bytes=adpt.write_bytes, write_requests=adpt.num_writes)

commit_message:
Pecan: rework notifier hook for registry callbacks

[1] and [2] were added to use the registry callback notifier for dhcp and nova
notifications for the legacy wsgi layer.  This adds the same functionality
to the pecan wsgi layer.  It just so happens to clean the code up nicely
and also fixes a bug that was introduced by [3] that caused an ever
increasing number of subscriptions to the registry callback notifier.

[1] I7440becb6d30af7159ecaeba09d7a28eceb71bea
[2] I1d7d4b80ee77deefce18df22f76cab81750c0397
[3] I607635601caff0322fd0c80c9023f5c4f663ca25

Change-Id: I0a8b64e7742283a9d6c6b42ebc27887836df69ec
Closes-Bug: #1633296

this is scoped to avoid a dependency on nova client when nova # notifications aren't enabled from neutron.notifiers import nova self._nova_notifier = nova.Notifier.get_instance() self._nova_notifier.send_network_change(action_resource, *args) def _notify_dhcp_agent(self, context, resource_name, action, resources): # NOTE(kevinbenton): we should remove this whole method in Ocata and # make plugins emit the core resource events plugin = manager.NeutronManager.get_plugin_for_resource(resource_name) notifier_method = '%s.%s.end' % (resource_name, action) # use plugin's dhcp notifier, if this is already instantiated agent_notifiers = getattr(plugin, 'agent_notifiers', {}) dhcp_agent_notifier = ( agent_notifiers.get(constants.AGENT_TYPE_DHCP) or dhcp_rpc_agent_api.DhcpAgentNotifyAPI() ) native_map = getattr(dhcp_agent_notifier, 'uses_native_notifications', {}) if native_map.get(resource_name, {}).get(action): return # The DHCP Agent does not accept bulk notifications for resource in resources: item = {resource_name: resource} LOG.debug("Sending DHCP agent notification for: %s", item) dhcp_agent_notifier.notify(context, item, notifier_method) if not action or action == 'get': # data of the original object data = {collection_name: state.request.context.get('original_resources', [])} else: try: data = jsonutils.loads(state.response.body) except ValueError: if not state.response.body: data = {} resources = [] if data: if resource_name in data: resources = [data[resource_name]] elif collection_name in data: # This was a bulk request resources = data[collection_name] # Send a notification only if a resource can be identified in the # response. This means that for operations such as add_router_interface # no notification will be sent if cfg.CONF.dhcp_agent_notification and data: self._notify_dhcp_agent( neutron_context, resource_name, action, resources) if cfg.CONF.notify_nova_on_port_data_changes: orig = {} if action == 'update': orig = state.request.context.get('original_resources')[0] elif action == 'delete': # NOTE(kevinbenton): the nova notifier is a bit strange because # it expects the original to be in the last argument on a # delete rather than in the 'original_obj' position resources = ( state.request.context.get('original_resources') or []) for resource in resources: self._nova_notify(action, resource_name, orig, {resource_name: resource}) event = '%s.%s.end' % (resource_name, action) payload = {resource_name + '_id': resource_id} elif action in ('create', 'update'): if not resources: # create/update did not complete so no notification return if len(resources) > 1: payload = {collection_name: resources} else: payload = {resource_name: resources[0]} else: return self._notifier.info(neutron_context, event, payload)

commit_message:
Add documentation for add-on roles

This commit provides some basic documentation on how to use the
additional roles used by quickstart for CI and other tasks.

Change-Id: I2769ae5831f8a21904c223d06baf58b20081f940
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/33/346733/18 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ## Working With Other Roles TripleO Quickstart is more than just a tool for quickly deploying a single machine TripleO instance it is a general purpose framework for ci testing and automation. Add on roles for Quickstart are available from the [Redhat Openstack Github](https://github.com/redhat-openstack/) with the format ansible-role-tripleo-task-to-perform. To use these roles create a Python virtualenv to use as your working environment, by default Quickstart uses ~/.quickstart but for your own development we suggest you use your own environment. The steps below will create a python virtualenv and install the add on role into it. export WORKSPACE=/path/to/your/env virtualenv $WORKSPACE source $WORKSPACE/bin/activate cd $WORKSPACE git clone https://github.com/redhat-openstack/ansible-role-tripleo-task-to-add cd ansible-role-tripleo-task-to-add python setup.py install Perform the last three commands for every add on role you intend to use as well as for the TripleO Quickstart repository itself when you're done you will have a directory $WORKSPACE/playbooks with all the playbooks from Quickstart and the whatever extra roles you installed. From here you can use quickstart.sh to invoke whatever playbooks you are interested in using like so. cd $WORKSPACE/tripleo-quickstart ./quickstart.sh --playbook playbook.yml --working-dir $WORKSPACE Some roles are meant only to be added to an existing playbook, for example if you wanted to perform a pingtest to validate the overcloud you would clone the ansible-role-tripleo-overcloud-validate repository and then edit $WORKSPACE/playbooks/quickstart.yml like so. - name: Install undercloud and deploy overcloud hosts: undercloud gather_facts: no roles: - tripleo/undercloud - tripleo/overcloud - tripleo-overcloud-validate This will perform the pingtest validation after the deployment of the overcloud is finished.

commit_message:
Catch the integrityError when update firewall group with non exist port

When create/update firewall group should verify the port_id exist in
current system.

This patch add check in update firewall group operation to verify
the input ports are exist.

Change-Id: I98862ff46eb80b5f516dd02a0ab179017825a9c9
Closes-Bug: #1634086

added_lines: def test_update_firewall_group_with_non_exist_ports(self): """neutron firewall_group create test-policy """ with self.router(name='router1', admin_state_up=True, tenant_id=self._tenant_id) as r, \ self.subnet(cidr='30.0.0.0/24') as s: body = self._router_interface_action( 'add', r['router']['id'], s['subnet']['id'], None) port_id1 = body['port_id'] foo_port_id = 'caef152d-b118-4b9b-bc77-800661bf082d' fwg_ports = [port_id1] with self.firewall_group( name='test', default_policy=False, ports=fwg_ports, admin_state_up=True) as fwg1: self.assertEqual(const.INACTIVE, fwg1['firewall_group']['status']) data = {'firewall_group': {'ports': [foo_port_id]}} req = self.new_update_request('firewall_groups', data, fwg1['firewall_group']['id']) res = self.deserialize(self.fmt, req.get_response(self.ext_api)) self.assertEqual('FirewallGroupPortNotFound', res['NeutronError']['type']) self._router_interface_action('remove', r['router']['id'], s['subnet']['id'], None)

commit_message:
[install] Fix the incorrect flavor name

There is no flavor named "m1.tiny". Actually, "m1.nano" is created
to be used to create CirrOS server. The patch fixes it.

Change-Id: I74acb11122ec6da3c090a25bebc33e0b5e5aeb40
Closes-Bug: #1635465
